items.title: Canadian mining company employees worked amid gunfire, Mexican cartel checkpoints, says family member
items.summary_auto: Vizsla Silver Corp.'s workers laboured in an environment punctured by gunfire, cartel checkpoints and drones, says the brother of a geologist with the Canadian mining company in Mexico, who was among five people found dead after they were kidnapped by a suspected faction of the Sinaloa cartel.

items.title: Caregivers in region with Canada's oldest demographic call for more respite, seniors care
items.summary_auto: A delegation representing caregivers in the Oceanside region of mid-Vancouver Island delivered a petition to Qualicum Beach town council on Wednesday asking for more respite and seniors care facilities in the area.

items.title: Company behind proposed sand mining project partnering with U of Manitoba on groundwater monitoring research
items.summary_auto: An Alberta company that has proposed mining silica sand in Manitoba is partnering with the U of M on the experimental design of a groundwater monitoring network, using technology experts say is becoming more important for global groundwater research.

items.title: Rollout of electronic medical records undergoing changes after concerns raised
items.summary_auto: One of the officials tasked with overseeing the rollout of Nova Scotia’s $365-million electronic medical record system says lessons from the project’s debut at the IWK Health Centre are already being applied ahead of the next launch in the central health zone.

items.title: Ukrainian athlete Vladyslav Heraskevych out of Winter Olympics over banned helmet
items.summary_auto: Heraskevych came to the Olympics with a customized helmet showing the faces of more than 20 Ukrainian athletes and coaches who were killed during the war, a conflict that started shortly after the 2022 Beijing Games ended.

items.title: Neighbours raise safety concerns after squatters take up shelter in vacant downtown St. John's home
items.summary_auto: Squatters recently took up shelter in a vacant house in downtown St. John's, raising concerns amongst neighbours who worry about fire risks and public safety.

items.title: As schools process Tumbler Ridge shooting, officials say safety protocols need ongoing attention
items.summary_auto: School safety protocols, threat assessments and how schools prepare for active-shooter or similar emergency situations are under a renewed spotlight following Tuesday’s devastating mass shooting in the northeastern B.C. community of Tumbler Ridge.

items.title: Owner of St. Catharines, Ont., café fought Enbridge over $56K gas bill error — and won
items.summary_auto: Ritesh Kumar was ready to open his coffee shop, Christopher's Cafe, and rent out the apartment units upstairs. But then he got a bill from Enbridge Gas Inc. for $56,589.

items.title: Ambassador Bridge owners ramped up lobbying before Trump’s Gordie Howe threats
items.summary_auto: An analysis of U.S. federal lobbying and campaign finance data sheds fresh light on how the Moroun family has sought to influence the political landscape around the busiest land border crossing between the U.S. and Canada.

items.title: Trump is set to scrap a longstanding legal basis for U.S. climate action. Here's what that could mean
items.summary_auto: The Trump administration is expected this week to rescind a legal opinion that has guided emissions controls in the U.S. since the Obama era, withdrawing the so-called endangerment finding of the Environmental Protection Agency.

items.title: Ottawa commits to keeping Mounties on front lines, says fixing federal policing is priority
items.summary_auto: After months of uncertainty hanging over the RCMP, Public Safety Minister Gary Anandasangaree says the government is committed to keeping Mounties in the business of day-to-day policing across the country — while signalling that improving the federal crimes wing is his priority.

items.title: As tensions simmer between U.S. and Iran, Iraq is feeling the heat
items.summary_auto: Of the many proxy battlegrounds between Iran and the U.S., Iraq is one of the most overlooked, at least outside the Middle East. But U.S. reaction to the reappearance on the political scene of former Iraqi prime minister Nouri al-Maliki — a candidate for the job once more — is a sharp reminder of the tightrope Iraq walks between the two.

items.title: After Tumbler Ridge shooting, false claims about trans people have proliferated online
items.summary_auto: Anger and false claims are being directed at transgender people after Tuesday's mass shooting in Tumbler Ridge, B.C., that left nine people dead, including the suspected shooter, who RCMP identified as an 18-year-old transgender woman.

items.title: Central Alberta town faces uncertain future as it drowns in debt and faces potential insolvency
items.summary_auto: The future of the Town of Gibbons is on the line as its mayor and council say a multimillion-dollar financial crisis has come to a head after years of bad decisions.

items.title: Kraft Heinz halts plans to split company
items.summary_auto: Kraft Heinz has halted efforts to split the company, in a surprise move that new CEO Steve Cahillane said was necessary due to deteriorating conditions in the food industry, though ‌he called the challenges "fixable and within our control."

items.title: The fastest way to get into an Ontario LTC is by going a hospital first. That's a problem, say advocates
items.summary_auto: The fastest way to get into a long-term care home in Ontario is by going to the hospital first, advocates say.

items.title: Olympic viewing guide Day 6: Get ready for a big Thursday
items.summary_auto: CBC Sports' daily Olympics newsletter previews a stacked Day 6 for Canada, including some strong gold-medal chances and the men's hockey opener.

items.title: Canadian skaters Gilles and Poirier find peace with an Olympic medal moment a lifetime in the making
items.summary_auto: It’s impossible to pinpoint where the Olympic journey started for Piper Gilles and Paul Poirier, Canada’s ice dance champions. It had a thousand starting points.

items.title: Boy, 13, who stabbed little brother handed 3-year sentence designed for youth with mental health issues
items.summary_auto: A 13-year-old Lethbridge, Alta., boy who tried to kill his seven-year-old brother by stabbing him was handed a three-year sentence on Wednesday, the maximum term allowed under the Youth Criminal Justice Act.

items.title: Mayor of Portapique tells Tumbler Ridge 'we understand' mass shooting devastation
items.summary_auto: Colchester County Mayor Christine Blair relates what her community experienced after the 2020 mass shooting that killed 22 people in Nova Scotia to Tuesday's mass shooting in Tumbler Ridge, B.C., advising that 'it will be surreal.' Blair says her community has experienced multiple suicides, and that instead of just an initial surge of support, trauma therapists should be made available in B.C. 'on a regular basis for years to come.'

items.title: Sask. mine that could make Canada world's biggest uranium exporter faces last hurdle
items.summary_auto: Hearings now underway in Saskatoon could decide the future of Canada’s biggest uranium mining project to date. Indigenous communities are now on board, but the proponent, NexGen, is still waiting on final say from the Canadian Nuclear Safety Commission.

items.title: Text exchange that brought down Quebec Liberal leader was doctored, report finds
items.summary_auto: In a report commissioned by the party, a retired judge says the vote-buying scandal that ended Pablo Rodriguez’s stint as PLQ leader in late 2025 may have been sparked by manipulated evidence. The story that launched the scandal was published by the Journal de Montréal, which says the report commissioned by the PLQ is incomplete, that its author does not know the identity of their sources and that they stand by their reporting.

items.title: Trump meets with Netanyahu as Iran marks 47 years of Islamic rule
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump met with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Washington to discuss U.S. nuclear talks with Iran, but nothing definitive was decided. Meanwhile, thousands in Tehran marked the 47th anniversary of the Islamic Revolution.

items.title: Suspect's mother identified as 1 of 8 Tumbler Ridge, B.C., mass shooting victims
items.summary_auto: RCMP say nine people are dead in total, including the suspect, correcting their previous report of 10.

items.title: Yes, Canada has a 'fungus bank' — and it just got saved by a massive donation
items.summary_auto: A unique collection of microscopic fungi used for Canadian medical and biodiversity research has been saved from being shipped overseas.

items.title: Ukrainian Vladyslav Heraskevych is the most important athlete at the Olympics right now
items.summary_auto: The International Olympic Committee is not an organization that generally begs, but they are begging Ukrainian skeleton athlete Vladyslav Heraskevych not to compete in a customized helmet showing the faces of more than 20 Ukrainian athletes and coaches killed since Russian invaded Ukraine in 2022.

items.title: P.E.I. school officials didn’t mishandle complaints about substitute teacher, 3rd-party review finds
items.summary_auto: A review of sexual misconduct at P.E.I. schools sheds new light on what school officials knew about a substitute teacher who inappropriately touched students in the classroom — and when they knew it.

items.title: Vonn says she had 'successful' 3rd surgery on broken leg following alpine crash at Olympics
items.summary_auto: American skier Lindsey Vonn said Wednesday that she had a "successful" third surgery on her broken left leg following her downhill crash at the Olympics.

items.title: Dawson's Creek star James Van Der Beek dead at 48
items.summary_auto: James Van Der Beek, the actor best known for his role on 1990's TV show Dawson's Creek, has died. He was 48.
